Why is this phrase so helpful?

First of all, it‚Äôs important to remember that thinking is not the same as OVER-thinking. Thinking things through is good.

But overthinking is bad because:

-Life rarely plays out exactly the way you‚Äôve imagined it. 

-You spend hours, days, even months or years worrying about things that will never happen.

-It paralyzes you and prevents you from moving forward.

In contrast, when you run the experiment, you take this approach:

"I'm not sure of the right way. But I won't know unless I make a decision.

"So, let's pick one. If it works out great, awesome. If not, I'll have more data and can adjust‚Äîor, will know what to do next time."

There are very few irreversible decisions. When you run the experiment, you choose to move forward, rather than standing still. 

And since time is money, standing still often costs more than changing your mind.

As you run more and more experiments, you'll get into a repeated cycle of:

-think
-decide
-test
-learn
-adjust

That tight feedback loop will help you make better and better decisions over time.

So, the next time you find yourself overthinking, take a step back and...

Run the experiment.

Don't get me wrong‚ÄîI think we need more empathy in the world. Empathy helps us to understand and relate to others.

But here's the thing: If you leave your empathy unchecked, it'll take a heavy toll. That's because you can't really turn empathy "off." 

When others pour out their hearts to me, I take it all in. Unable to turn off my feelings, I‚Äôm often left feeling emotionally drained. And I'm not alone.

Research shows that nurses who work with terminally ill patients run a high risk of developing "compassion fatigue," a condition of physical and emotional depletion. It‚Äôs easy for caregivers like these to focus on the needs of their patients at the expense of their own, putting them on a path to burnout.

We can compare empathy to a muscle. Used in the right way, it allows you to ‚Äúlift‚Äù others up and even help carry their burdens. But like any muscle, it can become overworked.

The key, then, is to develop emotionally intelligent empathy‚Äîbalanced empathy that works for you, instead of against you.

How can you exercise your empathy muscle in an emotionally intelligent way?

A few tips: 

1. Give yourself buffer time.
If your job involves being around others much of the day, you may quickly find yourself emotionally exhausted.

To combat this, schedule buffer time between meetings or time with others. Take shorter, more frequent breaks that allow you to recharge your emotional batteries.

2. Set boundaries.
If you're spending time with someone who you know needs more than usual attention, set a time limit. You might even make an appointment that you have to meet at a certain time‚Äîeven if it's an appointment with yourself.

Of course, you don't want to rush away...but recognize that if every time you're with them you overspend your emotional budget, you'll probably start avoiding them altogether.

Your empathy muscle can be a major source of strength‚Äîbut only if you don‚Äôt work it to the point of breakdown.

So, work to understand your own emotional needs; then, act accordingly.

Of course, we always have our reasons. The money is good. The company is great. Change is hard. 

Sometimes we tell ourselves that maybe, just maybe, things will improve.

Toxic people rarely do.

And so, sadly, the onus is on us to get away ‚Äì and sooner rather than later. I know it feels unfair! 

But look at the upside ‚Äì like a photo of Maria‚Äôs beautiful face, creased with the wisdom of her years, which she was good enough to share with us.

I value a naughty little dachshund named Pierre and iced coffee, black. But I‚Äôm lucky that way, because if my research is correct, you probably don‚Äôt know yours.

Your values, that is. Yes, I‚Äôm serious.

We talk about values at work and at home all the time ‚Äì they matter. But my recent research at NYU Stern School of Business shows that only 17% of respondents who were asked, ‚ÄúWhat are your values?‚Äù could supply an answer. Most checked the box for ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt know,‚Äù or listed words that could best be described as virtues, such as ‚Äúgenerosity‚Äù and ‚Äúkindness.‚Äù Only a smattering of the 400 respondents, aged between 22-45 and in professional jobs, answered, ‚Äúfinancial security‚Äù or ‚Äúmoney.‚Äù¬† 

Because that‚Äôs another thing about values. Even when we know our own, they can be hard to admit out loud. They‚Äôre personal, or we fear they might strike other people the wrong way. 

In my class Becoming You, we spend two weeks doing activities and exercises that help us identify our values in gritty and serious detail. (For instance, Pierre and coffee are not technically values, but both reveal truer, deeper ones around self-determination and belonging.) Such inquiry is absolutely essential to the larger purpose of the class, which is answering the question, ‚ÄúWhat should I do with my life?‚Äù

But I would make the case that knowing your values is essential, period.

If you don‚Äôt know yours, my advice is to start trying to figure them out today. Books abound, and so do courses. And if you have 40 minutes to spare, you might also attend my totally free digital workshop on August 27 at 5 PM EST (link is the comments).¬† 

Look, values matter, as I said. If you know yours, let us know below how you got out of the 17%. ‚¨áÔ∏è If you don‚Äôt, keep searching. The sooner you find them, the sooner you can live into them, perhaps even with a crazy little pup (or two or three) by your side.

Every once in a while, you see research that makes you mutter, ‚ÄúI knew it,‚Äù to yourself. Or, in my rather immature case this week, makes you run around announcing, ‚ÄúI TOLD YOU SO!‚Äù to anyone who will listen.¬† 

I‚Äôm talking about a study, reported in the The New York Times, that suggests that the more you actively seek happiness, the less happy you tend to be. Indeed, the research seems to indicate that happiness as a life goal has been vastly overhyped and oversold.

So what are we to do? Give up on trying to be happy? Of course not. We just need to try¬†‚û° differently. ‚¨Ö ¬†Read all about it in this week‚Äôs newsletter. Trigger warning: There will be gloating.

News flash: The fastest way to get canceled is to suggest remote work could possibly, perhaps, maybe-maybe, compromise business effectiveness. 

That‚Äôs what former Google CEO Eric Schmidt just found out, as you might have heard, (https://lnkd.in/gvtK5wBa) but his experience is no surprise. Questioning remote work is a dangerous game out there. I once was quoted saying you probably would not become the CEO of a Fortune 500 company while working from home, and for the next 48 hours, I found out what it felt like to be Joan of Arc.

Can we please, please stop this polarized enmity and have a normal, rational, public conversation about an important issue that touches so many? I, for one, see the pros and cons of remote work. I think most of us do. I love spending the day with my dogs and can often be just as productive working from the comfort of my home office. (Pierre also approves.) But I have also experienced the 1+1 = 3 magic of having everyone brainstorming in a room together. For instance, I am working with Perpetual right now to build a digital product, and our in-person meetings are undeniably more creative and productive. Sorry not sorry. 

I fully support anyone who makes the decision to work 100% remote, and I fully support the companies that require their people to be in the office some or all of the time. The world is big enough, and there is enough talent and opportunity to go around, that these two groups can co-exist without acrimony. 

Or am I just being too logical?

Real leadership means having the courage to be (gulp) hated. 

I, for one, cannot claim this super power. Blame my genes. Blame my upbringing. Blame my general wimpiness. I like it when everyone is happy. (And, even better, when no one is mad at me too.)

But think about it: Hasn‚Äôt every truly transformational leader you‚Äôve ever known been kind of fearless? Actually, scratch ‚Äúkind of.‚Äù

They‚Äôve been bold, decisive, and risk-embracing, haters be damned. 

I can‚Äôt be like them, but I can really, truly admire them. 

Case in point: Uma Valeti, MD, the CEO of UPSIDE Foods, who just today filed a lawsuit against Florida, demanding it reverse its ban on the sale of cultivated meat. https://lnkd.in/e-5ZZ2pW

You may find animal-loving, plant-based folks (like me) annoying, overly sensitive, or just plain wrong. But you have to respect a start-up that takes on one of the world‚Äôs most powerful and well-funded special interest groups, the U.S. Agriculture Lobby.

That is conviction of purpose.

When Upside Foods succeeds, and I believe it will, people will speak of the company‚Äôs courage. And I will be among them ‚Äì recalling the first time I tasted cultivated meat in my own kitchen, with Uma and Bruce Friedrich of the The Good Food Institute.

Right now, however, Upside is making history with its legal challenge, and it won‚Äôt be pretty.¬† 

Leadership (gulp again) can‚Äôt always be.

"What we're really discussing is not whether this new technology is problematic in and of itself‚Äîcreating images that look real but aren't is literally nothing new‚Äîbut instead the potential dangers of making such powerful tools available to billions of people. And that, I agree, is a genuine concern.

As AI becomes more prevalent it stands to reason that it becomes increasingly more important to disclose exactly when an image has been manipulated; it's a safety issue."

This quote is from an essay I published yesterday on MBH4H. Later that same day, The Verge's Chris Welch published an incredible set of pictures using Google's "reimagine" feature as part of his review of the Pixel 9 phones, and... well, the photos speak for themselves.

Chris managed to add car wrecks, a helicopter crash, drug paraphernalia, and even corpses in a crash scene to his photos in a matter of seconds just by typing a prompt.

As I wrote in my piece yesterday, all of these photo editing techniques have been available to photographers for decades. However, this level of retouching was time-consuming, difficult, and required powerful computers.

But what I find genuinely alarming is that there is nothing to alert the viewer to the fact that the image has been altered (except deep down in the metadata). It's not so much what "reimagine" can do but the speed with which it can do it.

Yesterday, I wrote that putting these AI tools in phones "is a genuine concern." After seeing the photos in Chris's review, that was a monumental understatement.

Move fast and take things, episode... honestly I've lost count.
